name: Cuba
currentCrisisSummary:
Cuba faces a severe and protracted crisis, driven by two co-equal factors: the six-decade-long **unilateral US economic blockade** and **catastrophic internal state mismanagement**.

The **blockade** is an act of **economic warfare** that deliberately strangles the island's economy, restricting food, medicine, and finance. This **external coercion** is compounded by a **one-party authoritarian state** whose own **disastrous 2021 monetary reform (*Tarea Ordenamiento*)** triggered **hyperinflation** and destroyed savings. This dual crisis of **external pressure** and **internal failure** fuels chronic shortages, state collapse, and mass emigration.

imperialRoot.legacy:
Cuba's history is defined by **imperial dependency**. **Spanish rule** established a **plantation economy**. The **US intervened** in 1898, transforming the island into a **neo-colony** governed by **US-backed dictators** (Batista).

The 1959 revolution rejected **US domination** but, to survive the subsequent **US blockade**, established a new dependency as a **client state of the Soviet Union**. The **Special Period** (1991) was the result of this **Soviet imperial patronage** collapsing. Cuba's modern crisis is defined by the legacy of these successive dependencies.

historicalContext.title: The US Blockade: Economic Warfare
historicalContext.description: Implemented in 1962, the **US blockade** is a web of restrictions suffocating the economy. It prohibits transactions, penalises third-country companies (**extraterritoriality**), blocks access to finance, and impedes imports. Intensified by laws like **Helms-Burton** (1996), the **blockade** explicitly aims to cause suffering to compel regime change, violating Cuban sovereignty and **international law**.

historicalContext.title: Internal Mismanagement: The *Tarea Ordenamiento*
historicalContext.description: The 2021 ***Tarea Ordenamiento*** (monetary reform) was a **catastrophic internal shock** separate from the blockade. The state's ill-conceived unification of its dual-currency system **triggered runaway hyperinflation**, instantly vaporised the value of salaries and savings, and decimated production. This **state-engineered economic collapse** is a primary driver of the current humanitarian crisis.

historicalContext.title: Authoritarianism and the 11J Protests
historicalContext.description: The crisis is also political. The state is a **one-party authoritarian system** that represses all dissent. The historic **July 11, 2021 (11J) protests**â€”the largest anti-government demonstrations since 1959â€”were a popular uprising against shortages and dictatorship. They were met with a **brutal state crackdown**, mass arrests, show trials, and long prison sentences, cementing **political repression** as a co-equal driver of mass emigration.

historicalContext.title: Collapse of Soviet Dependency (**Special Period**)
historicalContext.description: The collapse of the **Soviet Union** (1991)â€”Cuba's **imperial patron**â€”caused a devastating crisis (**Special Period**). This revealed the economy's deep **structural dependency** on Soviet subsidies (sugar-for-oil). The US exploited this vulnerability by intensifying the **blockade** (**Helms-Burton Act**), aiming for total collapse.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: The **US blockade** is overwhelmingly condemned internationally (**UN General Assembly** votes). Its **extraterritorial** nature breaches international norms. The US maintains it due to domestic politics and its **imperial objective** of controlling Cuba.

humanitarianImpact.title: Access to Medicine
humanitarianImpact.description: Chronic shortages caused by **blockade restrictions** and a **state-led production collapse**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Challenges accessing affordable food due to **blockade-imposed limits** and **domestic hyperinflation**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Economic Hardship
humanitarianImpact.description: Widespread poverty resulting from the **blockade** *and* **internal hyperinflation** caused by failed state reforms.

humanitarianImpact.title: Migration Crisis
humanitarianImpact.description: Large-scale emigration driven by **economic desperation** (from the blockade *and* internal mismanagement) *and* **political repression**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Infrastructure Decay
humanitarianImpact.description: Difficulties maintaining infrastructure due to **blockade preventing access** to parts and **state insolvency**.

timeline.event: **Spanish Colonial Rule**: Following Columbus's arrival, Spain colonises Cuba, establishing a brutal plantation economy based on Indigenous genocide, imported African slave labour, and the extraction of sugar and tobacco wealth for the Spanish Crown.
**US Intervention & Neo-Colony**: The US intervenes in Cuba's war of independence, seizing control from Spain and establishing a neo-colonial relationship codified by the Platt Amendment (1901).
**Batista Dictatorship**: US-backed dictator Fulgencio Batista rules, enriching elites and foreign corporations while brutally suppressing dissent.
**Cuban Revolution**: Fidel Castro's revolutionary movement overthrows Batista, initiating radical social reforms and challenging US dominance.
**Bay of Pigs Invasion**: A CIA-organised invasion by Cuban exiles attempts to overthrow the revolutionary government but is decisively defeated.
**US Blockade Imposed**: The US imposes a comprehensive economic blockade designed to cripple the Cuban economy and force regime change.

**Special Period**: The collapse of the Soviet Unionâ€”Cuba's primary economic and military patronâ€”triggers a severe economic crisis, exacerbated by the US tightening the blockade (Helms-Burton Act, 1996).

**Internal Collapse & 11J Protests**: The state implements a disastrous monetary reform (***Tarea Ordenamiento***), triggering hyperinflation. In response to this and decades of repression, the largest popular protests since 1959 (11J) erupt and are met with a violent state crackdown and mass arrests.

donate.organisation: ACERE (Alliance for Cuba Engagement and Respect)
donate.description: Coalition advocating for an end to the US blockade and promoting respectful engagement with Cuba (Advocacy/Info, not direct aid).
Facilitates direct humanitarian aid and remittances to individuals and families in Cuba, bypassing government structures.

advocacy.title: Lift the Blockade
advocacy.description: Demand the immediate and unconditional lifting of the US economic blockade against Cuba, which functions as collective punishment.

advocacy.title: End Fraudulent Terror Designation
advocacy.description: Call for Cuba's removal from the US list of 'State Sponsors of Terrorism,' a politically motivated designation used to justify sanctions.

advocacy.title: Demand Political Freedom
advocacy.description: Support the right of the Cuban people to peaceful protest and demand the release of all political prisoners, including those detained during the **11J protests**.

advocacy.title: Respect Sovereignty
advocacy.description: Oppose all forms of US interference in Cuba's internal affairs and support Cuban sovereignty.

advocacy.title: Support Free Travel & Exchange
advocacy.description: Support campaigns for unrestricted travel and cultural exchange between the US and Cuba.

reading.title: *Open Veins of Latin America: Five Centuries of the Pillage of a Continent*
reading.description: Eduardo Galeano's essential history of colonial and imperialist exploitation in Latin America, providing vital context.

reading.title: *Cuba and the U.S. Empire: A Chronological History*
reading.description: Jane Franklin provides a detailed chronology of US aggression and intervention against Cuba since the revolution.

reading.title: *Che Guevara: A Revolutionary Life*
reading.description: Jon Lee Anderson's definitive biography offers deep insight into the Cuban Revolution and its key figures.
